comment_0: This is about a high class call girl, or whore, or prostitute, whatever you wanna call it, that is what it is...
comment_1:
I hate to be the one to point out the obvious, but Gunpowder, Gelatin & Dynamite are 3 basic explosives. They are all volatile, dangerous. Exciting! Throw in the Lazer Beam for a good rhyme and more raw energy.

Freddy did confess on several occassions that this song was just about a high society call girl. In particular, I agree with psa09140: Freddy had Christine Keeler in mind when he wrote the song. But, most people on this list are WAY too young to know who she is.

Also: wazojugs -- Margaret Thatcher was not PM when the song was written in 1974. Learn something about history.
comment_2:
This song has absolutely nothing to do with homosexuality.  

Freddy Mercury said:

"It's about a high class call girl. I'm trying to say
that classy people can be whores as well. That's what
the song is about, though I'd prefer people to put
their own interpretation upon it - to read what they like into it."

He did say that it is open to interpretation.  I would take it a step further and say that it is about a female assassin / secret agent who poses as a high-class prostitute.

Throughout the song it refers to the technology she uses as a secret agent / assassin:


Gunpowder
Dynamite
Laser Beam
(not sure about the reference to gelatine)

Other references to her secret agent / assassin:

-Of course, the most obvious, she's a "Killer Queen"
-Khrushchev and Kennedy- they were key figures during the cold war....it implies that she spies for one or the other or both
-met a man from China, possibly a target of hers
-never kept the same address (covert)
-Fastidious and precise

Then of course all of the references to her "cover" as a prostitute and how well she played the part:

-champagne, caviar, perfume, etc.
-well versed in etiquette
-blow your mind (double meaning- sex and also assassin)
-recommended at the price (this could also be a reference to her work as an assassin or prostitute)
-reference to Marie Antoinette, the queen of France
-Geisha (not sure about Minah...it is a legend of the Sisters' Islands...off the islands of Singapore....maybe a place she had to go for her secret agent work)
-spoke like a baroness
-Insatiable an appetite

Apparently she is out the business for a spell:
"Then momentarily out of action
Temporarily out of gas"

An awful lot of information in a song of 3 minutes 1 second!!
comment_4:
I hate to be a b*tch, but every line gives its own answer...many of your comments refer to historical inaccuracies due to timelines...here we go...

Everything up through the first chorus is referring in general to the well-groomed "Will and Grace" & "Queer Eye for the Straight Guy" gay man.  

The Kruschev and Kennedy line is basically referring to "if they'd just get it over with and make it then everything would be fine."

Dynamite with a laser beam.  Are you freaking kidding me?  Are there no gay men on this site?  Laser beam is weenie!

Gunpowder/gelatin think people think...what shoots out of a "laserbeam" and is a sticky gelatin substance?

Guaranteed to BLOW your mind! Do you really not get this yet?

Insatiable an appetite...a common stereotype for gay men.

To avoid complications, she never kept the same address.  Yes, yes, yes! You got it, a high class TRANNY, well paid at that.

The Geisha line refers to the most famous of all transvestites, Madame Butterfly!  I can't believe no one got that one

If you are that way inclined...again, how literal does Freddy have to be for you guys to get it.

Momentarily out of action...a female prostitute could go all night, but a male would need a short period for recovery, ya know.

If you think playful as a pussycat refers to a woman, think again.  It refers to a man who is as COY as a woman.

Some people think the last lines are "wanna try..wanna try" they are actually "What a Drag"

That says it all... now, if you want to take an introductory poetry class, let me know.  The first thing you'd learn is that metaphors are not mixed.  A message in a poem is generally consistent.  Freddy Mercury is one of the greatest poets in music.  I doubt he'd mix his metaphors.

Sorry again to be so bitchy.
comment_5: People are used to hard rock, energy music from Queen, yet with this single you almost expect Noel Coward to sing it. It's one of those bowler hat, black suspender belt numbers â not that Coward would wear that. (...) It's about a high class call girl. I'm trying to say that classy people can be whores as well. That's what the song is about, though I'd prefer people to put their interpretation upon it â to read into it what they like. -Freddie Mercury

comment_18:
This song in no way speaks of a woman being a prostitute.

Instead it speaks of a confident woman, with accumen, cultured tastes, who defines herself, instead of allowing others to do it.  She is educated and wise to the ways of the world, and because she is complez and not "common" in her ways or means, is bequiling to others.  More of a conquest and a curiosity.

This role in ancient times might have been a "Courtesan", who was not simply a subject for sexual pleasures, but sought after for her company.  A woman who was independent, made her own means, was highly educated and refined, and able to position herself as more of an equal to men than other women of her times.

comment_20:
It is absurd to expect Mr. Mercury to name the subject lady of Killer Queen. There would be a lawsuit.
But the mention of "Kruschev and Kennedy" (who married JFK?), "Paris" (who hailed from French aristocracy, who got her clothes and perfume from Chanel, who had a BA in French lit, and visited Paris frequently), she smoked cigarettes, Well versed in etiquette, Her stepson (Alexander Onasis called her "the geisha".
"You wanna try?. You wanna try" Heck, EVERY man wanted to. "Playful as a pussycat" may reference her catalog of affairs and her later reclusive life "momentarily out of action".

Makes sense to me.

comment_28:
Alright well first of all,, This song has absolutely nothing to do with aids. Aids was discovered in the early 80's and freddy mercury was diagnosed in 1988, He kept it a secret from the public untill 1991. On the 23rd November Freddie confirmed the worst by issuing a statement saying that he did in fact have AIDS. At 7pm the next day Freddie's fight was over.

  And because this song was released in 1974, in the sheer heart attack album there is no possibility it was. I like Number6's definiton of the song, but i always thought it was a high class prostitute. Never keeping the same adress etc etc. 

 Its a great song, One of queens best. Followed only by Flash, Bohemian Rhapsody, We are the champions and a few others. 

   Queen rules ;)

comment_43: This is easy!  Killer Queen is about Christine Keeler:get it? (Keeler - Killer)  Hence the reference to Khruschchev & Kennedy.  Check it out & you'll see what Freddie was trying to say. Currently teaching a '60s college course & was planning to use the lyrics as a class assignment.  Saw all the comments & had to write.  Great song, too!
comment_44: Probably a stupid meaning, but anyway... I always thought it was about drugs (which Freddie Mercury knew a lot about, remember) - with lines like 'Wanna try?', 'Little man from China' (a sort of contrived smuggling connection?) and the whole atmosphere of extravagant self-destruction. All the stuff about 'Guaranteed to blow your mind', 'insatiable an appetite' and 'recommended at the price' kind of ties in as well - on the other hand, it ties in just as well with the prostitute theory. Since Freddie Mercury was experienced in both, it could have been deliberately designed to be ambigous.
comment_45: In a 1974 interview, Freddie said this: "It's about a high class call girl. I'm trying to say that classy people can be whores as well. That's what the song is about, though I'd prefer people to put their interpretation upon it - to read into it what they like." So, if you want to think it's about homosexuality or transvestites, or whatever, go right ahead. (the interview is at: geocities.com/SunsetStrip/Stadium/5025/… for anyone who's interested.)

comment_119: The reference to Marie Antoinette is something that came out of the French Revolution, but she did not say it out of being callous. Poor Marie didn't seem to have too much going on above her chin. When she was told the peasants were revolting because they didn't have any bread, she thought that they literally were upset because they had no bread for dinner. So she suggested, "Well, if their out of bread, have them eat cake." She was just plain a dolt, and thought she had solved the problem.
comment_120:
I think you can interpret this song in several ways.  Obviously, the high-class prostitute is one interpretation.  

I enjoy thinking of it in a little more creative fashion, a la "La Femme Nikita." She's a beautiful, elegant woman who is really a covert governmental operative.  The reference to "Kruschev and Kennedy" certainly supports this interpretation, as do the references to various weapons.

Another similar interpretation is that this is simply a dangerous woman to get involved with.  She's irresistible but the men who fall for her end up getting hurt emotionally.  

Finally, one much looser interpretation is that "she's" a drag queen.

comment_124: This song is about a murdererâs imaginary friend. The murderer has a fetish for the woman hand. He only kills when it is absolutely necessary. He just wants to live a quiet life indulging in his hobbies without being troubled by anyone. comment_125: In fact I see this song as a high class prostitute with a "double personality", who both serves high class men and is a serial killer between them - so as a "killer queen", "To avoid complications She never kept the same address" as one would do.
comment_126: RedShana's interpretation above comes fairly close to what I believe this song is about. Kudos RS! Well thought out and you don't miss much. I agree the song is about a high end prostitute. The prostitute is definitely male. People please, when interpreting something try to remember WHEN it was written and performed. This was the 70s. We had to rely on inuendo and be very clandestine, especially as regards what now would be called LGBT subject matter. Often the true meanings were laid between the lines, although I agree with RedShana, Freddie was pretty clear on most of this, for anyone who was tuned in and looking for it. Killer Queen is about a man who is a seemingly delightful very high end prostitute for men. Although I love the idea of the assasin someone had, I know that isn't really what the song is about. Also, someone said something about AIDS, um no! This song was written before AIDS was on anyone's mind. That didn't come until the 80s. Also, "killer" was a way of saying something was extremely good/cool, etc. As in, "did you see the new movie? It's killer, you got to see it." So, to sum up, KQ rocks out about a high end male prostitute for gentlemen, who is a real pleasant, playful, charming type to the lucky clients, and therefore, comes highly recommended.
comment_127:
After some research based on the time period of the song and historical references in the lyrics I have concluded that this song is about Jacqueline Kennedy Onasis.  

The first verse is key.  The reference and metaphor for her French heritage -  âshe keeps MoÃ«t en Chandon in her pretty cabinetâ.   Her pretty cabinet is herself and her fashionable clothing.

âLet then eat cake just like Marrie Antonette â. Again refers to her French lineage and perhaps the authors perception of her callousness and ignorance at the beginning of her run as First Lady.

âA Built -in remedy for Krushev and Kennedy.â  Jacqueline accompanied the president on a trip to meet Krushevâ. Tellingly, Krushev made it a point to shake hands with Jacqueline before the president.  She was built-in referring to she was the First Lady and not external to the situation.

An Iâmvitation  Krushev could not decline.  Nor could she decline on the handshake.  She obviously had some impact on the diplomatic resolution.  


âCaviar and cigarettes, well versed in etiquette, extraordinarily niceâ. She came from a wealthy family, went to boarding school in France. 


âsheâs a Killer Queen, Gunpowder gelatine, dynamite with a laser beam, guaranteed to blow your mindâ. Refers to her power, sheâs a queen in her own right as First Lady to JFK.    She is noted as having an erratic personality,  At times paranoid, unstable and other times as confident and effective. 

The erratic nature of her personality is also conveyed in the bridge âdrop of a hat ......â


The  China reference âmet a man from China went down to Ghiesha Minah:  Jacqueline Kennedy after the assignation hired Chinese born I.M. Pei as architect to design the JFK Memorial Library and Museum.  She ended up on trip with him to China but that was in 1982 years after the song was written.  The went down to Geisha Minah  may be a metaphor for , well you know.

I might be totally off base here but it was interesting analyzing these somewhat cryptic lyrics.  Love the song by the way.
comment_128: This I reckon is all about someone he couldn't have. It's nothing to do with prostitutes.
comment_129:
(Warning: Excuse my grammar errors if I have, IÂ´m hispano and have not totally domain English language)

Ever I've thought Killer Queen is about a high class woman -just, quoting Freddy here- that degeneres herself into a whore. She started to use drugs. And harder and harder until she turn off into a whore to earn money for drugs.

Beginning with Wine, simple socialization drug:
"She keeps her Moet et Chandon
In her pretty cabinet"

Then she starts to be careless with his own alcohol consumption, without limitations. She justifies herself acting like ' it's my life, let me stay, let me consume the sweet-things that I like '. The MA reference, I supose, is an insinuation about high class people that uses his money without care:
"'Let them eat cake', she says
Just like Marie Antoinette"

I think this part talks about how easier is to make a deal drinking. And yep, it includes more high class people:
"A built-in remedy
For Kruschev and Kennedy"

Here her high class life and her consumption starts to oppose:
"At anytime an invitation
You can't decline"

Now she is mixing her two styles of life, her caviar (high class) and her cigarettes (consumer life). Acting with etiquette but really she's just drugged, that felling so nice:
"Caviar and cigarettes
Well versed in etiquette
Extraordinarily nice"

I see the chorus parts like a hole in the narration, functions like a transition of years or months without importance. In this time she tests stronger things and degeneres herself.

I think 'Killer Queen' not refers at the protagonist. It referes to the drugs, they can kill you, or kill your high class reputation, your queen reputation. Then the lyrics describes the drug-effects she test. Drugs that makes you feel the world like gelatine, drugs that free your mind  and makes feel like gunpowder:
"She's a Killer Queen
Gunpowder, gelatine"

Maybe I'm wrong about this part. In latin america, at the 60's and 70's, 'dynamite' was an euphemism for weed, Idk if that was equals in other countries outside. However, "dynamite with a laser beam", I think it means that she use drugs strongers than simple-weed:
"Dynamite with a laser beam
Guaranteed to blow your mind
Anytime"

Stronger drugs are expensive, and make you addict:
"Recommended at the price
Insatiable an appetite
Wanna try?"

I have a problem with my interpretation, the next two verses are in past, and I can't explain that.

Now she run away. His high class life over:
"To avoid complications
She never kept the same address"

Eventualy, she pretends to be high class with a china-guy. Maybe she is steling him, or maybe they are stealing together:
"In conversation
She spoke just like a baroness
Met a man from China"

This part have many possible interpretation. It's a pun with Asia Minor that include the word Geisha, so, an interpretation is: her modus operandi for steal is be a minor geisha (a whore that acts in reunions); or: she turn off into a geisha (for get money for drugs) in a region of Asia.
"Went down to Geisha Minah"

I think she's stealing with her geisha act 'cause it seems logic, there's not a real evidence in the lyrics. Now she continue her thefts (again, and again), knowing it's bad, but his addiction forces her (incline in that way) to do it:
"Then again incidentally
If you're that way inclined"

Paris is another reference to high class style of life. Her act is requested on better sites (or more privates). Now she's more expensive and finer (like a perfumed whore) and doesn't care, she just acts for the money:
"Perfume came naturally from Paris (naturally)
For cars she couldn't care less
Fastidious and precise"

Another chorus part. So, the time pass.

Now her geisha act is over. She's totally a whore, doing the necessary for money:
"Drop of a hat she's as willing as
Playful as a pussy cat"

This part describes her current situation, she have few and little moments un-drugged. (the first line refers she doesn't works drugged):
"Then momentarily out of action
Temporarily out of gas
To absolutely drive you wild, wild"

The last pre-chorus line isn't about the protagonist, it's about the 'Killer Queen', about the drugs:
"She's all out to get you"

Last time the chorus. The time pass.

Lyrics finishes with a simple not-invitacion sentence, Killer Queen story continues, never gonna over:
"You wanna try."

comment_139:
I think this is overall a mockery of certain high class lifestyles. The comparison to Marie Antoinette(a note to the person that thinks the entire song is about Antoinette: if so, then why is she likened to herself?) seems to suggest that she isn't very intelligent, while the 'gunpowder...laser beam' would then be metaphors for the reckless methods by which she remains popular, despite her limited intelligence.

Then, the woman being loose ('...quaranteed to blow your mind // anytime...')  contrasts with her  classy appearance('...well versed in etiquette...'), illustrating the difference between how the high class may act, and how they actually behave.
